message_1: A sample of Uranium-238 has an initial activity of 300 Bq. If the half-life of Uranium-238 is 4.47 billion years, what will be its activity after 9 billion years?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

Activity_final = Activity_initial * (1/2)^(time_elapsed / half_life)

where Activity_final is the activity after 9 billion years, Activity_initial is the initial activity (300 Bq), time_elapsed is the time that has passed (9 billion years), and half_life is the half-life of Uranium-238 (4.47 billion years).

Activity_final = 300 Bq * (1/2)^(9 billion years / 4.47 billion years)

Now, we can calculate the exponent:

Exponent = 9 billion years / 4.47 billion years = 2.014

Activity_final = 300 Bq * (1/2)^2.014

Activity_final ≈ 300 Bq * 0.242

Activity_final ≈ 72.6 Bq

After 9 billion years, the activity of the Uranium-238 sample will be approximately 72.6 Bq.
